archetypes.name: Hopeful Democrat
archetypes.desc: Believes in gradual progress and institutional reform; sees America as imperfect but improving. Votes Democratic with confidence rather than fear.
archetypes.examples: Joe Biden, Tim Walz, Obama coalition optimists

archetypes.name: Sunrise Conservative
archetypes.desc: Morning-in-America optimism; believes in American dynamism and that conservative policies will restore prosperity. Forward-looking rather than defensive.
archetypes.examples: Reagan heirs, Chamber of Commerce optimists, Nikki Haley

archetypes.name: Heritage Conservative
archetypes.desc: Defends traditional culture and hierarchy against perceived threats; cultural identity is central to politics.

archetypes.name: Heritage Fortress Conservative
archetypes.desc: Maximum cultural defense posture; pessimistic about reversing decline but committed to holding the line.

archetypes.name: Quiet Middle
archetypes.desc: Holds no strong political views; content with status quo and avoids political engagement. Politics is irrelevant distraction. 'I just want to grill.'
archetypes.examples: Michael Jordan (1990s), Derek Jeter, Tim Duncan

archetypes.name: Rising Tide Progressive
archetypes.desc: Believes progress lifts everyone; combines social liberalism with genuine optimism about human potential and positive-sum politics.

archetypes.name: Prosperity Democrat
archetypes.desc: Focuses on bread-and-butter issues but believes smart economic policy can grow the pie for everyone. Solutions-oriented, less combative than populist wing.
archetypes.examples: Jason Furman types, pragmatic union leaders, suburban economic Democrats

archetypes.name: Institutional Progressive
archetypes.desc: Works through established institutions to achieve progressive goals; believes in reform within the system.
archetypes.examples: Hillary Clinton, Nancy Pelosi, Chuck Schumer

archetypes.name: Global Citizen Liberal
archetypes.desc: Sees humanity as interconnected; prioritizes international cooperation and universal human rights over national boundaries.
archetypes.examples: Samantha Power, Angelina Jolie, George Clooney

archetypes.name: Full Spectrum Conservative
archetypes.desc: Combines free-market economics with traditional values and strong national identity; Reaganite fusion conservative.
archetypes.examples: Ted Cruz, Ron DeSantis, Marco Rubio

archetypes.name: Class Conflict Progressive
archetypes.desc: Views politics through lens of class struggle; corporations and billionaires are the enemy. Economic redistribution is the terminal goal.

archetypes.name: Markets-First Conservative
archetypes.desc: Economic freedom is the primary value; government intervention in markets is the main concern. Culture is secondary.
archetypes.examples: Steve Forbes, Larry Kudlow, Art Laffer

archetypes.name: Statistical Middle
archetypes.desc: Represents the mathematical center of American opinion; no strong ideological commitments on any dimension.

archetypes.name: Faith and Family Traditionalist
archetypes.desc: Religious faith and scripture are the foundation of political knowledge; family and church structure are paramount.

archetypes.name: Evidence-Based Progressive
archetypes.desc: "Follow the data" as methodology for achieving progressive ends. Epistemology is instrumental but load-bearing.

archetypes.name: Evidence-Based Free Marketer
archetypes.desc: Supports markets based on empirical evidence of efficiency; economics-first worldview grounded in data.
archetypes.examples: Larry Summers, Greg Mankiw, Tyler Cowen

archetypes.name: Movement Conservative
archetypes.desc: Committed ideological conservative active in the movement; fuses economics, culture, and nationalism with combative style.

archetypes.name: Expanding Pie Moderate
archetypes.desc: Believes growth can benefit everyone; seeks win-win solutions across partisan lines. Positive-sum worldview is central.

archetypes.name: Parish Traditionalist
archetypes.desc: Faith rooted in local community and inherited tradition; the church as anchor against a changing world. Heritage-preserving, locally focused religious voter.
archetypes.examples: Traditional parish leaders, Southern Baptist community, Orthodox congregations

archetypes.name: Cultural Regionalist
archetypes.desc: Regional/cultural identity drives politics; "common sense" epistemology; suspicious of outsiders and elites.

archetypes.name: Identity-Rooted Progressive
archetypes.desc: Lived experience and testimony are epistemically central; ethno-racial identity drives political positions.

archetypes.name: Rationalist Libertarian
archetypes.desc: Derives political positions from first principles and logical deduction; believes in human reason and markets.

archetypes.name: Movement Progressive
archetypes.desc: Politics is about vision and hope; the aesthetic of uplift and inspiration IS the politics.

archetypes.name: Prophetic Progressive
archetypes.desc: Moral witness IS the politics; speaking truth to power regardless of effectiveness.

archetypes.name: Competitive Conservative
archetypes.desc: Politics is competition; pro-market but sees economy as zero-sum race.

archetypes.name: Idealist Progressive
archetypes.desc: Believes in human perfectibility through reason; transformative potential of collective action.

archetypes.name: Entrepreneurial Conservative
archetypes.desc: Pro-business moderate who believes entrepreneurship solves social problems; not strongly partisan.
archetypes.examples: Michael Bloomberg, Mark Cuban, Howard Schultz

archetypes.name: Quiet Conservative
archetypes.desc: Holds conservative views but avoids political engagement; votes but doesn't advocate.

archetypes.name: Globally Minded Social Democrat
archetypes.desc: Combines progressive economics with cosmopolitan internationalism; believes in global cooperation.

archetypes.name: Siege Mentality Partisan
archetypes.desc: Sees politics as existential warfare between in-group and threatening out-groups.
archetypes.examples: Marjorie Taylor Greene, Steve Bannon, Matt Gaetz

archetypes.name: Neighborhood Democrat
archetypes.desc: Progressive on economics, rooted in local community and often faith tradition.

archetypes.name: Team Player Capitalist
archetypes.desc: Strongly pro-business but primarily motivated by partisan team loyalty.

archetypes.name: Rising Tide Social Democrat
archetypes.desc: Believes redistribution can happen through growth, not conflict; abundance mentality.

archetypes.name: Free-Thinking Moderate
archetypes.desc: Takes positions from both parties; resists ideological conformity and tribal pressure. Actually has no partisan lean; evaluates each election independently.
archetypes.examples: Bill Maher, Joe Rogan (2015–2020), Angus King

archetypes.name: Optimistic Progressive
archetypes.desc: Culturally liberal with genuine optimism about human nature and social progress.

archetypes.name: Deliberative Centrist
archetypes.desc: The quality of democratic conversation IS the value; civility matters intrinsically.

archetypes.name: Cosmopolitan Centrist
archetypes.desc: Globally-oriented moderate who values international institutions and cultural openness. Non-partisan with universalist values; heterodox on most issues.
archetypes.examples: Fareed Zakaria, Thomas Friedman, Steven Pinker

archetypes.name: Rooted Centrist
archetypes.desc: Strong attachment to local community and civic institutions but centrist on economics/culture.

archetypes.name: Win-Win Centrist
archetypes.desc: Believes most political problems have solutions that benefit everyone; actively seeks compromise.
archetypes.examples: Larry Hogan, Charlie Baker, Jon Huntsman

archetypes.name: All-In Traditionalist
archetypes.desc: Maximum commitment to traditional values, hierarchy, and in-group boundaries; no compromise.

archetypes.name: Borderless Moderate
archetypes.desc: Skeptical of national boundaries and in-group preferences; believes in universal humanity.

archetypes.name: Common Ground Seeker
archetypes.desc: Actively seeks compromise across partisan divides; frustrated by tribalism on both sides.

archetypes.name: Neoliberal Progressive
archetypes.desc: Socially liberal, economically market-friendly; believes markets and social progress are compatible.
archetypes.examples: Matt Yglesias, Noah Smith, Elon Musk (2012–2020)

archetypes.name: Policy Over Party
archetypes.desc: Evaluates policies on merits rather than party affiliation; frustrated with partisan tribalism.
archetypes.examples: Mitt Romney (2019–), Liz Cheney (2021–), Kyrsten Sinema (2020–)

archetypes.name: Solutions-Oriented Moderate
archetypes.desc: Focuses on practical problem-solving rather than ideological purity.

archetypes.name: Hardline Movement Conservative
archetypes.desc: Combines aggressive capitalism with authoritarian cultural conservatism; outcomes justify means.

archetypes.name: Global Markets Libertarian
archetypes.desc: Believes in free markets and free trade across borders; economically libertarian globalist.

archetypes.name: Data-Driven Democrat
archetypes.desc: Left-leaning but epistemology is load-bearing; follows evidence to progressive conclusions.

archetypes.name: Working-Class Traditionalist
archetypes.desc: Economically left, culturally conservative working-class; wants redistribution but distrusts cultural outsiders. The 'Obama-Trump' crossover type.
archetypes.examples: Robert Casey Sr. †, Huey Long †, Father Coughlin †

archetypes.name: Cosmopolitan Libertarian
archetypes.desc: Socially liberal, economically libertarian, globally oriented; dislikes both parties equally.

archetypes.name: Culturally Cautious Centrist
archetypes.desc: Centrist on economics but cautious about rapid cultural change.
archetypes.examples: Suburban moderates uneasy with cultural progressivism

archetypes.name: Conflict-Minded Progressive
archetypes.desc: Believes fundamental transformation requires confrontation with entrenched power.

archetypes.name: Structure and Community
archetypes.desc: Values social order, hierarchy, and strong community bonds.

archetypes.name: Community-Rooted Progressive
archetypes.desc: Progressive values rooted in strong community or faith tradition.

archetypes.name: Independent Social Democrat
archetypes.desc: Supports social democratic policies but dislikes Democratic Party establishment.

archetypes.name: Mutual Aid Progressive
archetypes.desc: Focuses on being a good community member; believes in local cooperation and mutual aid.

archetypes.name: Neoliberal
archetypes.desc: Free markets plus social liberalism; globalist, pro-immigration, optimistic about growth.

archetypes.name: Ordoliberal
archetypes.desc: Social market economy; markets need strong rules and institutions to function fairly.

archetypes.name: Christian Democrat
archetypes.desc: Center-right with religious moral framework; supports welfare state within traditional values.

archetypes.name: Market Socialist
archetypes.desc: Worker ownership combined with market mechanisms; anti-capitalist but not anti-market.

archetypes.name: Georgist
archetypes.desc: Land value tax as primary policy; believes unearned land rents are the source of inequality.

archetypes.name: Civic Republican
archetypes.desc: Active citizenship and civic virtue are essential; constitutional process is sacred. Freedom through participation; popular sovereignty within constitutional bounds.
archetypes.examples: Hannah Arendt tradition, Federalist Society members, Larry Kramer

archetypes.name: Communitarian Centrist
archetypes.desc: Strong communities over individual rights; moderate on economics and culture.

archetypes.name: Third Way Democrat
archetypes.desc: Triangulation between left and right; market-friendly progressivism. Pro-business, socially liberal, pragmatic.

archetypes.name: Rockefeller Republican
archetypes.desc: Fiscally conservative, socially moderate; old-school northeastern Republican.

archetypes.name: Catholic Worker
archetypes.desc: Radical Catholic social teaching; pacifist, pro-poor, anti-state.

archetypes.name: Distributist
archetypes.desc: Widespread property ownership; against both big business and big government.

archetypes.name: Agrarian Populist
archetypes.desc: Rural-focused; suspicious of banks, corporations, and urban elites.

archetypes.name: Localist
archetypes.desc: Local self-governance is paramount; skeptical of all distant authority.

archetypes.name: Mutualist
archetypes.desc: Market anarchism; free markets without capitalism, mutual credit.

archetypes.name: Guild Socialist
archetypes.desc: Worker control through trade guilds or councils; decentralized socialism with workplace democracy.

archetypes.name: Conservative Socialist
archetypes.desc: Economic leftism combined with cultural conservatism; working-class traditionalist.

archetypes.name: National Conservative
archetypes.desc: Nation-state as primary unit; cultural preservation, skeptical of globalism.

archetypes.name: Civic Nationalist
archetypes.desc: National identity based on civic values, not ethnicity; patriotic liberal.

archetypes.name: Minarchist
archetypes.desc: Minimal state; only police, courts, military. Night-watchman state.

archetypes.name: Anarcho-Communist
archetypes.desc: Abolish state and capitalism; mutual aid and gift economy.

archetypes.name: Syndicalist
archetypes.desc: Revolutionary trade unionism; workers control through direct action.

archetypes.name: Primitivist
archetypes.desc: Civilization is the problem; return to pre-industrial or pre-agricultural life.

archetypes.name: Transhumanist
archetypes.desc: Technology will transcend human limitations; embrace enhancement.

archetypes.name: Post-Ideological Technocrat
archetypes.desc: Expert rule; policy should be determined by technical knowledge.

archetypes.name: Meritocrat
archetypes.desc: Reward talent and effort; inequality is acceptable if earned.

archetypes.name: Elitist Democrat
archetypes.desc: Democracy needs competent leadership; not all opinions equal on technical matters.

archetypes.name: Fortress Traditionalist
archetypes.desc: Scarcity-driven authoritarianism; zero-sum resource thinking, hierarchical traditionalism, siege mentality.

archetypes.name: National Bolshevik
archetypes.desc: Synthesis of far-left economics and far-right nationalism.

archetypes.name: Traditional Cosmopolitan
archetypes.desc: Holds traditional values but applies them universally to all humans, not just their own tribe. Believes in timeless moral truths that transcend cultural and national boundaries. May be religious universalist or natural law adherent.
archetypes.examples: Catholic social teaching adherents, natural law philosophers, some religious humanitarians, cosmopolitan conservatives

archetypes.name: Post-Left Anarchist
archetypes.desc: Beyond traditional anarchism; individualist, anti-organizational.

archetypes.name: Dark Enlightenment
archetypes.desc: Neoreaction; democracy is a failed experiment, return to traditional authority.

archetypes.name: Radical Centrist
archetypes.desc: Synthesize best ideas from all sides; reject tribal politics.

archetypes.name: Anti-Politics
archetypes.desc: Politics itself is the problem; withdrawal, prefigurative alternatives.

archetypes.name: Techno-Feudalist
archetypes.desc: Tech platform oligarchy as new feudalism; accepts this as inevitable.

archetypes.name: Post-Scarcity Utopian
archetypes.desc: Automation will eliminate scarcity; prepare for abundance.
archetypes.examples: Fully automated luxury space communism memes

archetypes.name: Fully Automated Luxury Communist
archetypes.desc: FALC; technology enables communist utopia without sacrifice.

archetypes.name: Survival Pragmatist
archetypes.desc: Too focused on economic survival to engage in politics; sees politics as zero-sum but irrelevant to daily life.
archetypes.examples: Working multiple jobs; politics is a luxury

archetypes.name: Private-Life Progressive
archetypes.desc: Progressive values but not politically engaged; lives values privately.
archetypes.examples: Socially liberal professionals who avoid politics

archetypes.name: Identity Networker
archetypes.desc: Politics is primarily social; votes how their community votes.

archetypes.name: Rule-Following Citizen
archetypes.desc: Participates through proper channels; believes in following rules and procedures.

archetypes.name: Online Spectator
archetypes.desc: Highly engaged online but doesn't participate offline; politics as entertainment.
archetypes.examples: Twitter power users who never vote

archetypes.name: Quiet Dissident
archetypes.desc: Silently disagrees with both parties; keeps head down and disengages.

archetypes.name: Constitutional Purist
archetypes.desc: Constitutional process is sacred; outcomes are legitimate only if process is. Will oppose "their side" on procedural grounds.
archetypes.examples: Ron Paul (civil liberties), some ACLU types

archetypes.name: Norm Guardian
archetypes.desc: Institutionalist who cares about norms above outcomes; "how we do things" defines political identity.
archetypes.examples: Adam Kinzinger, David French, Liz Cheney (J6 focus)

archetypes.name: Technocratic Free Marketer
archetypes.desc: Markets + evidence + proper process; technocratic governance as ideal. Depoliticization is the goal.

archetypes.name: Rationalist Technocrat
archetypes.desc: First-principles reasoning + technical competence; believes rational analysis should drive policy.

archetypes.name: Street Advocate
archetypes.desc: Protest-oriented activist; believes in direct action and movement politics; prophetic style in the streets.
archetypes.examples: DeRay Mckesson, John Lewis †, Dolores Huerta

archetypes.name: Burkean Epistemicist
archetypes.desc: Tradition is *how we know*, not just *what we prefer*; reason is limited; accumulated wisdom trumps abstract theory.

archetypes.name: Armchair Analyst
archetypes.desc: Loves analyzing politics but never participates; pundit mindset without action.

archetypes.name: Deliberative Moderate
archetypes.desc: HOW we engage is the core political issue; incivility and polarization are the primary problems.

archetypes.name: Evidence-First Reformer
archetypes.desc: Progressive goals, evidence-based methods, principled about process; reform must be both effective and sound.

archetypes.name: Nonpartisan Activist
archetypes.desc: Highly engaged in politics but refuses partisan identity; advocates for issues rather than parties. Believes both parties are captured by special interests.
archetypes.examples: Ralph Nader, some civic reform advocates, League of Women Voters activists

archetypes.name: Issue-First Independent
archetypes.desc: Votes based on specific issues rather than party loyalty; highly engaged but switches parties based on candidates and issues.

archetypes.name: Civic Engagement Maximalist
archetypes.desc: Believes participation itself is the highest political value; votes, volunteers, attends meetings regardless of party. Process-focused independent.

archetypes.name: Digital Warrior
archetypes.desc: Extremely combative online but rarely participates offline. Politics as spectator sport and identity performance. High engagement online, zero offline.
archetypes.examples: Twitter/Reddit political posters who never vote, reply guys

archetypes.name: Armchair Combatant
archetypes.desc: Loves political arguments and debate but sees voting as pointless. High conflict engagement, low civic participation.
archetypes.examples: Political podcast addicts who don't vote, debate club alumni

archetypes.name: Reluctant Partisan
archetypes.desc: Would prefer to be independent but feels forced to choose sides by polarization. High engagement, uncomfortable with party identity.
archetypes.examples: 'I'm not a Democrat, I just always vote for them', Never-Trumpers

archetypes.name: Social Liberal Moderate
archetypes.desc: Fiscally centrist but socially progressive; open to cultural change while pragmatic on economics. Common among educated suburbanites.
archetypes.examples: Suburban moderates who vote on social issues, 'socially liberal, fiscally moderate' types

archetypes.name: Social Conservative Moderate
archetypes.desc: Fiscally centrist but culturally traditional; values stability and tradition while pragmatic on economics. Common in rural and religious communities.
archetypes.examples: Rural moderates, church-going centrists uncomfortable with both parties

archetypes.name: Progressive Civic Nationalist
archetypes.desc: Progressive economics framed through American civic identity; believes in shared national purpose, worker solidarity, and cross-partisan coalition building. Patriotic framing of progressive goals. Visionary rather than technocratic.
archetypes.examples: Ro Khanna, Tim Ryan (economic focus), some Bernie coalition members

archetypes.name: Social Civic Nationalist
archetypes.desc: Social democratic economics combined with civic nationalism. Believes in rebuilding American identity around civic participation, shared democratic values, and economic solidarity. Policy-focused rather than populist; sees national cohesion through inclusive institutions.
archetypes.examples: Union Democrats, civic renewal advocates, some New Deal coalition inheritors

archetypes.name: Vigilant Democrat
archetypes.desc: Worried about democratic backsliding, climate crisis, or authoritarian threats; votes with urgency and alarm. Sees elections as existential battles.

archetypes.name: Fortress Conservative
archetypes.desc: Feels traditional America is under siege from cultural and demographic change; votes defensively to preserve what remains of the country they knew.
archetypes.examples: Laura Ingraham listeners, cultural anxiety voters

archetypes.name: Fighting-Class Democrat
archetypes.desc: Sees economics as zero-sum struggle between workers and the powerful; combative 'fighting for working families' framing. Economic combat, not wonkery.
archetypes.examples: Sherrod Brown supporters, union Democrats, populist left

archetypes.name: Social Gospel Voter
archetypes.desc: Faith calls them to universal justice—welcoming the stranger, caring for the poor, healing the world. Cosmopolitan, interfaith-friendly, progressive religious tradition.
archetypes.examples: William Barber, Jim Wallis, liberation theology Catholics, progressive evangelicals

archetypes.name: Doomer Leftist
archetypes.desc: "It's all rigged." Disengaged or purely expressive politics.

archetypes.name: Reform-Optimist Progressive
archetypes.desc: Institutions can be reformed to achieve transformative goals.

archetypes.name: Pragmatic Establishmentarian
archetypes.desc: Works within institutions because that's what works; no illusions about transformation.

archetypes.name: Progress Capitalist
archetypes.desc: Markets plus progress can solve everything; techno-optimist.

archetypes.name: Pragmatic Neoliberal
archetypes.desc: Markets are the least bad option; no illusions about perfection.

archetypes.name: Institutional Skeptic
archetypes.desc: Believes in human potential but distrusts institutions. Sees bureaucracies, corporations, and governments as corrupting forces that stifle human goodness. Prefers grassroots, community-based, and direct approaches over institutional channels.
archetypes.examples: Some localists, mutual aid organizers, back-to-land movement, skeptical community activists

archetypes.name: Siege Mentality Conservative
archetypes.desc: Traditional values are under permanent attack from hostile forces; defensive, embattled, sees betrayal everywhere.
archetypes.examples: Culture war conservatives, Benedict Option types

archetypes.name: Aspirational Kitchen Table Democrat
archetypes.desc: Believes hard work leads to prosperity; optimistic about economic mobility and the American Dream.

archetypes.name: Anxious Kitchen Table Democrat
archetypes.desc: Worried about economic security and falling behind; needs reassurance that the system hasn't forgotten them.

archetypes.name: Grievance-Activated Populist
archetypes.desc: No coherent ideology; activated by zero-sum framing and anti-elite messaging. Votes AGAINST system, not FOR policy. First-time Trump voter archetype.
archetypes.examples: 2016 Obama→Trump voters; non-voters activated by Trump

archetypes.name: Decline-Anxious Swing Voter
archetypes.desc: High threat sensitivity; responds to "things are getting worse" messaging. Swings based on which party seems more threatening. No coherent ideology.
archetypes.examples: Anxious swing voters in Rust Belt

founders.name: George Washington
founders.title: First President, Commander-in-Chief
founders.quote: Liberty, when it begins to take root, is a plant of rapid growth.
founders.desc: The indispensable man who held the nation together through sheer force of character. Cautious with power, he set precedents that would last centuries.

founders.name: John Adams
founders.title: Second President, First Vice President
founders.quote: Facts are stubborn things; and whatever may be our wishes, our inclinations, or the dictates of our passion, they cannot alter the state of facts and evidence.
founders.desc: A brilliant legal mind and fierce advocate for independence. Trusted institutions over populism and believed in ordered liberty through law.

founders.name: Thomas Jefferson
founders.title: Third President, Author of Declaration
founders.quote: I hold it that a little rebellion now and then is a good thing, and as necessary in the political world as storms in the physical.
founders.desc: The philosopher of American liberty who believed in the wisdom of common people. Championed agrarian democracy and limited government.

founders.name: James Madison
founders.title: Fourth President, Father of Constitution
founders.quote: If men were angels, no government would be necessary.
founders.desc: The architect of checks and balances who understood both the necessity and danger of power. Master of political theory turned practical statesman.

founders.name: Alexander Hamilton
founders.title: First Treasury Secretary
founders.quote: Those who stand for nothing fall for anything.
founders.desc: The self-made genius who built America's financial system from scratch. Believed in strong central government, national banks, and manufacturing.

founders.name: Benjamin Franklin
founders.title: Diplomat, Inventor, Sage
founders.quote: They who can give up essential liberty to obtain a little temporary safety deserve neither liberty nor safety.
founders.desc: America's first citizen of the world. Combined practical wisdom with philosophical depth, believing in self-improvement and civic virtue.

founders.name: John Jay
founders.title: First Chief Justice, Federalist
founders.quote: Those who own the country ought to govern it.
founders.desc: The architect of American jurisprudence and first Chief Justice. A devout Christian, abolitionist, and institutionalist who believed the republic's survival depended on law, order, and moral governance.

founders.name: Samuel Adams
founders.title: Father of the American Revolution
founders.quote: It does not take a majority to prevail, but rather an irate, tireless minority keen to set brush fires in people's minds.
founders.desc: The original American populist who organized the Sons of Liberty and the Boston Tea Party. Deeply puritanical, fiercely nationalist, and distrustful of elites and centralized power. Believed virtue came from the common people, not institutions.

founders.name: Thomas Paine
founders.title: Revolutionary Pamphleteer
founders.quote: These are the times that try men's souls. The summer soldier and the sunshine patriot will, in this crisis, shrink from the service of their country.
founders.desc: The most radical voice of the Revolution who went further than any founder. Advocated wealth redistribution, abolition, women's rights, and world revolution. Rejected organized religion, monarchy, and aristocracy in all forms.
